intro: Ipomoea dissecta var. acuta, commonly known as the sharpleaf morning glory, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is characterized by its heart-shaped, deeply lobed leaves and trumpet-shaped, violet to blue flowers that bloom in the morning. The plant is an annual vine that thrives in moist, sunny environments, often found in woodlands and along stream banks. Its rapid growth and showy flowers make it a popular ornamental plant, though it can become invasive in certain regions. The species is part of the Convolvulaceae family, known for its climbing habit and distinctive floral structures.
